Text: KENNEDY: Mr. Smith, Mr. Nixon.
Speech: Mr. Smith, Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: In the election of 1860, Abraham Lincoln said the question was whether this nation could exist half-slave or half-free.
Speech: In the election of 1860, Abraham Lincoln said the question was whether this nation could exist half-slave or half-free.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: In the election of 1960, and with the world around us, the question is whether the world will exist half-slave or half-free, whether it will move in the direction of freedom, in the direction of the road that we are taking, or whether it will move in the direction of slavery.
Speech: In the election of 1960, and with the world around us, the question is whether the world will exist half-slave or half-free, whether it will move in the direction of freedom, in the direction of the road that we are taking, or whether it will move in the direction of slavery.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think it will depend in great measure upon what we do here in the United States, on the kind of society that we build, on the kind of strength that we maintain.
Speech: I think it will depend in great measure upon what we do here in the United States, on the kind of society that we build, on the kind of strength that we maintain.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: We discuss tonight domestic issues, but I would not want that to be any implication to be given that this does not involve directly our struggle with Mr. Khrushchev for survival.
Speech: We discuss tonight domestic issues, but I would not want that to be any implication to be given that this does not involve directly our struggle with Mr. Khrushchev for survival.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Khrushchev is in New York, and he maintains the Communist offensive throughout the world because of the productive power of the Soviet Union itself.
Speech: Mr. Khrushchev is in New York, and he maintains the Communist offensive throughout the world because of the productive power of the Soviet Union itself.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Chinese Communists have always had a large population.
Speech: The Chinese Communists have always had a large population.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: But they are important and dangerous now because they are mounting a major effort within their own country.
Speech: But they are important and dangerous now because they are mounting a major effort within their own country.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The kind of country we have here, the kind of society we have, the kind of strength we build in the United States will be the defense of freedom.
Speech: The kind of country we have here, the kind of society we have, the kind of strength we build in the United States will be the defense of freedom.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we do well here, if we meet our obligations, if we're moving ahead, then I think freedom will be secure around the world.
Speech: If we do well here, if we meet our obligations, if we're moving ahead, then I think freedom will be secure around the world.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we fail, then freedom fails.
Speech: If we fail, then freedom fails.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Therefore, I think the question before the American people is: Are we doing as much as we can do?
Speech: Therefore, I think the question before the American people is: Are we doing as much as we can do?
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Are we as strong as we should be?
Speech: Are we as strong as we should be?
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Are we as strong as we must be if we're going to maintain our independence, and if we're going to maintain and hold out the hand of friendship to those who look to us for assistance, to those who look to us for survival?
Speech: Are we as strong as we must be if we're going to maintain our independence, and if we're going to maintain and hold out the hand of friendship to those who look to us for assistance, to those who look to us for survival?
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I should make it very clear that I do not think we're doing enough, that I am not satisfied as an American with the progress that we're making.
Speech: I should make it very clear that I do not think we're doing enough, that I am not satisfied as an American with the progress that we're making.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: This is a great country, but I think it could be a greater country; and this is a powerful country, but I think it could be a more powerful country.
Speech: This is a great country, but I think it could be a greater country; and this is a powerful country, but I think it could be a more powerful country.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied to have fifty percent of our steel-mill capacity unused.
Speech: I'm not satisfied to have fifty percent of our steel-mill capacity unused.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Because economic growth means strength and vitality; it means we're able to sustain our defenses; it means we're able to meet our commitments abroad.
Speech: Because economic growth means strength and vitality; it means we're able to sustain our defenses; it means we're able to meet our commitments abroad.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when we have over nine billion dollars worth of food - some of it rotting - even though there is a hungry world, and even though four million Americans wait every month for a food package from the government, which averages five cents a day per individual.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when we have over nine billion dollars worth of food - some of it rotting - even though there is a hungry world, and even though four million Americans wait every month for a food package from the government, which averages five cents a day per individual.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I saw cases in West Virginia, here in the United States, where children took home part of their school lunch in order to feed their families because I don't think we're meeting our obligations toward these Americans.
Speech: I saw cases in West Virginia, here in the United States, where children took home part of their school lunch in order to feed their families because I don't think we're meeting our obligations toward these Americans.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when the Soviet Union is turning out twice as many scientists and engineers as we are.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when the Soviet Union is turning out twice as many scientists and engineers as we are.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when many of our teachers are inadequately paid, or when our children go to school part-time shifts.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when many of our teachers are inadequately paid, or when our children go to school part-time shifts.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we should have an educational system second to none.
Speech: I think we should have an educational system second to none.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when I see men like Jimmy Hoffa - in charge of the largest union in the United States - still free.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when I see men like Jimmy Hoffa - in charge of the largest union in the United States - still free.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied when we are failing to develop the natural resources of the United States to the fullest.
Speech: I'm not satisfied when we are failing to develop the natural resources of the United States to the fullest.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Here in the United States, which developed the Tennessee Valley and which built the Grand Coulee and the other dams in the Northwest United States at the present rate of hydropower production - and that is the hallmark of an industrialized society - the Soviet Union by 1975 will be producing more power than we are.
Speech: Here in the United States, which developed the Tennessee Valley and which built the Grand Coulee and the other dams in the Northwest United States at the present rate of hydropower production - and that is the hallmark of an industrialized society - the Soviet Union by 1975 will be producing more power than we are.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: These are all the things, I think, in this country that can make our society strong, or can mean that it stands still.
Speech: These are all the things, I think, in this country that can make our society strong, or can mean that it stands still.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not satisfied until every American enjoys his full constitutional rights.
Speech: I'm not satisfied until every American enjoys his full constitutional rights.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: If a Negro baby is born - and this is true also of Puerto Ricans and Mexicans in some of our cities - he has about one-half as much chance to get through high school as a white baby.
Speech: If a Negro baby is born - and this is true also of Puerto Ricans and Mexicans in some of our cities - he has about one-half as much chance to get through high school as a white baby.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: He has one-third as much chance to get through college as a white student.
Speech: He has one-third as much chance to get through college as a white student.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: He has about a third as much chance to be a professional man, about half as much chance to own a house.
Speech: He has about a third as much chance to be a professional man, about half as much chance to own a house.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: He has about uh - four times as much chance that he'll be out of work in his life as the white baby.
Speech: He has about uh - four times as much chance that he'll be out of work in his life as the white baby.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we can do better.
Speech: I think we can do better.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't want the talents of any American to go to waste.
Speech: I don't want the talents of any American to go to waste.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I know that there are those who want to turn everything over to the government.
Speech: I know that there are those who want to turn everything over to the government.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't at all.
Speech: I don't at all.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want the individuals to meet their responsibilities.
Speech: I want the individuals to meet their responsibilities.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I want the states to meet their responsibilities.
Speech: And I want the states to meet their responsibilities.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I think there is also a national responsibility.
Speech: But I think there is also a national responsibility.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The argument has been used against every piece of social legislation in the last twenty-five years.
Speech: The argument has been used against every piece of social legislation in the last twenty-five years.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The people of the United States individually could not have developed the Tennessee Valley; collectively they could have.
Speech: The people of the United States individually could not have developed the Tennessee Valley; collectively they could have.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: A cotton farmer in Georgia or a peanut farmer or a dairy farmer in Wisconsin and Minnesota, he cannot protect himself against the forces of supply and demand in the market place; but working together in effective governmental programs he can do so.
Speech: A cotton farmer in Georgia or a peanut farmer or a dairy farmer in Wisconsin and Minnesota, he cannot protect himself against the forces of supply and demand in the market place; but working together in effective governmental programs he can do so.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Seventeen million Americans, who live over sixty-five on an average Social Security check of about seventy-eight dollars a month, they're not able to sustain themselves individually, but they can sustain themselves through the social security system.
Speech: Seventeen million Americans, who live over sixty-five on an average Social Security check of about seventy-eight dollars a month, they're not able to sustain themselves individually, but they can sustain themselves through the social security system.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't believe in big government, but I believe in effective governmental action.
Speech: I don't believe in big government, but I believe in effective governmental action.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I think that's the only way that the United States is going to maintain its freedom.
Speech: And I think that's the only way that the United States is going to maintain its freedom.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: It's the only way that we're going to move ahead.
Speech: It's the only way that we're going to move ahead.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we can do a better job.
Speech: I think we can do a better job.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we're going to have to do a better job if we are going to meet the responsibilities which time and events have placed upon us.
Speech: I think we're going to have to do a better job if we are going to meet the responsibilities which time and events have placed upon us.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: We cannot turn the job over to anyone else.
Speech: We cannot turn the job over to anyone else.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: If the United States fails, then the whole cause of freedom fails.
Speech: If the United States fails, then the whole cause of freedom fails.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I think it depends in great measure on what we do here in this country.
Speech: And I think it depends in great measure on what we do here in this country.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The reason Franklin Roosevelt was a good neighbor in Latin America was because he was a good neighbor in the United States.
Speech: The reason Franklin Roosevelt was a good neighbor in Latin America was because he was a good neighbor in the United States.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: Because they felt that the American society was moving again.
Speech: Because they felt that the American society was moving again.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want us to recapture that image.
Speech: I want us to recapture that image.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want people in Latin America and Africa and Asia to start to look to America; to see how we're doing things; to wonder what the resident of the United States is doing; and not to look at Khrushchev, or look at the Chinese Communists.
Speech: I want people in Latin America and Africa and Asia to start to look to America; to see how we're doing things; to wonder what the resident of the United States is doing; and not to look at Khrushchev, or look at the Chinese Communists.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: That is the obligation upon our generation.
Speech: That is the obligation upon our generation.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: In 1933, Franklin Roosevelt said in his inaugural that this generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny.
Speech: In 1933, Franklin Roosevelt said in his inaugural that this generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think our generation of Americans has the same rendezvous.
Speech: I think our generation of Americans has the same rendezvous.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: The question now is: Can freedom be maintained under the most severe tack - attack it has ever known?
Speech: The question now is: Can freedom be maintained under the most severe tack - attack it has ever known?
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think it can be.
Speech: I think it can be.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I think in the final analysis it depends upon what we do here.
Speech: And I think in the final analysis it depends upon what we do here.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think it's time America started moving again.
Speech: I think it's time America started moving again.
Speaker: KENNEDY
Name: John F. Kennedy

Text: NIXON: Mr. Smith, Senator Kennedy.
Speech: Mr. Smith, Senator Kennedy.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The things that Senator Kennedy has said many of us can agree with.
Speech: The things that Senator Kennedy has said many of us can agree with.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There is no question but that we cannot discuss our internal affairs in the United States without recognizing that they have a tremendous bearing on our international position.
Speech: There is no question but that we cannot discuss our internal affairs in the United States without recognizing that they have a tremendous bearing on our international position.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There is no question but that this nation cannot stand still; because we are in a deadly competition, a competition not only with the men in the Kremlin, but the men in Peking.
Speech: There is no question but that this nation cannot stand still; because we are in a deadly competition, a competition not only with the men in the Kremlin, but the men in Peking.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're ahead in this competition, as Senator Kennedy, I think, has implied.
Speech: We're ahead in this competition, as Senator Kennedy, I think, has implied.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But when you're in a race, the only way to stay ahead is to move ahead.
Speech: But when you're in a race, the only way to stay ahead is to move ahead.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I subscribe completely to the spirit that Senator Kennedy has expressed tonight, the spirit that the United States should move ahead.
Speech: And I subscribe completely to the spirit that Senator Kennedy has expressed tonight, the spirit that the United States should move ahead.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Where, then, do we disagree?
Speech: Where, then, do we disagree?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think we disagree on the implication of his remarks tonight and on the statements that he has made on many occasions during his campaign to the effect that the United States has been standing still.
Speech: I think we disagree on the implication of his remarks tonight and on the statements that he has made on many occasions during his campaign to the effect that the United States has been standing still.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world.
Speech: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now last year, of course, was 1958.
Speech: Now last year, of course, was 1958.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That happened to be a recession year.
Speech: That happened to be a recession year.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But when we look at the growth of G.N.P.
Speech: But when we look at the growth of G.N.P.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today.
Speech: this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: More about that later.
Speech: More about that later.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Looking then to this problem of how the United States should move ahead and where the United States is moving, I think it is well that we take the advice of a very famous campaigner: Let's look at the record.
Speech: Looking then to this problem of how the United States should move ahead and where the United States is moving, I think it is well that we take the advice of a very famous campaigner: Let's look at the record.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Is the United States standing still?
Speech: Is the United States standing still?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Is it true that this Administration, as Senator Kennedy has charged, has been an Administration of retreat, of defeat, of stagnation?
Speech: Is it true that this Administration, as Senator Kennedy has charged, has been an Administration of retreat, of defeat, of stagnation?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Is it true that, as far as this country is concerned, in the field of electric power, in all of the fields that he has mentioned, we have not been moving ahead.
Speech: Is it true that, as far as this country is concerned, in the field of electric power, in all of the fields that he has mentioned, we have not been moving ahead.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, we have a comparison that we can make.
Speech: Well, we have a comparison that we can make.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have the record of the Truman Administration of seven and a half years and the seven and a half years of the Eisenhower Administration.
Speech: We have the record of the Truman Administration of seven and a half years and the seven and a half years of the Eisenhower Administration.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: When we compare these two records in the areas that Senator Kennedy has - has discussed tonight, I think we find that America has been moving ahead.
Speech: When we compare these two records in the areas that Senator Kennedy has - has discussed tonight, I think we find that America has been moving ahead.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's take schools.
Speech: Let's take schools.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have built more schools in these last seven and a half years than we built in the previous seven and a half, for that matter in the previous twenty years.
Speech: We have built more schools in these last seven and a half years than we built in the previous seven and a half, for that matter in the previous twenty years.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's take hydroelectric power.
Speech: Let's take hydroelectric power.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have developed more hydroelectric power in these seven and a half years than was developed in any previous administration in history.
Speech: We have developed more hydroelectric power in these seven and a half years than was developed in any previous administration in history.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let us take hospitals.
Speech: Let us take hospitals.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We find that more have been built in this Administration than in the previous Administration.
Speech: We find that more have been built in this Administration than in the previous Administration.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The same is true of highways.
Speech: The same is true of highways.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's put it in terms that all of us can understand.
Speech: Let's put it in terms that all of us can understand.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We often hear gross national product discussed and in that respect may I say that when we compare the growth in this Administration with that of the previous Administration that then there was a total growth of eleven percent over seven years; in this Administration there has been a total growth of nineteen percent over seven years.
Speech: We often hear gross national product discussed and in that respect may I say that when we compare the growth in this Administration with that of the previous Administration that then there was a total growth of eleven percent over seven years; in this Administration there has been a total growth of nineteen percent over seven years.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That shows that there's been more growth in this Administration than in its predecessor.
Speech: That shows that there's been more growth in this Administration than in its predecessor.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But let's not put it there; let's put it in terms of the average family.
Speech: But let's not put it there; let's put it in terms of the average family.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What has happened to you?
Speech: What has happened to you?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We find that your wages have gone up five times as much in the Eisenhower Administration as they did in the Truman Administration.
Speech: We find that your wages have gone up five times as much in the Eisenhower Administration as they did in the Truman Administration.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What about the prices you pay?
Speech: What about the prices you pay?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We find that the prices you pay went up five times as much in the Truman Administration as they did in the Eisenhower Administration.
Speech: We find that the prices you pay went up five times as much in the Truman Administration as they did in the Eisenhower Administration.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What's the net result of this?
Speech: What's the net result of this?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This means that the average family income went up fifteen per cent in the Eisenhower years as against two percent in the Truman years.
Speech: This means that the average family income went up fifteen per cent in the Eisenhower years as against two percent in the Truman years.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, this is not standing still.
Speech: Now, this is not standing still.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But, good as this record is, may I emphasize it isn't enough.
Speech: But, good as this record is, may I emphasize it isn't enough.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: A record is never something to stand on.
Speech: A record is never something to stand on.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It's something to build on.
Speech: It's something to build on.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in building on this record, I believe that we have the secret for progress, we know the way to progress.
Speech: And in building on this record, I believe that we have the secret for progress, we know the way to progress.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I think, first of all, our own record proves that we know the way.
Speech: And I think, first of all, our own record proves that we know the way.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy has suggested that he believes he knows the way.
Speech: Senator Kennedy has suggested that he believes he knows the way.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I respect the sincerity which he m- which he makes that suggestion.
Speech: I respect the sincerity which he m- which he makes that suggestion.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But on the other hand, when we look at the various programs that he offers, they do not seem to be new.
Speech: But on the other hand, when we look at the various programs that he offers, they do not seem to be new.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They seem to be simply retreads of the programs of the Truman Administration which preceded it.
Speech: They seem to be simply retreads of the programs of the Truman Administration which preceded it.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I would suggest that during the course of the evening he might indicate those areas in which his programs are new, where they will mean more progress than we had then.
Speech: And I would suggest that during the course of the evening he might indicate those areas in which his programs are new, where they will mean more progress than we had then.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What kind of programs are we for?
Speech: What kind of programs are we for?
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We are for programs that will expand educational opportunities, that will give to all Americans their equal chance for education, for all of the things which are necessary and dear to the hearts of our people.
Speech: We are for programs that will expand educational opportunities, that will give to all Americans their equal chance for education, for all of the things which are necessary and dear to the hearts of our people.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We are for programs, in addition, which will see that our medical care for the aged are - is - are much - is much better handled than it is at the present time.
Speech: We are for programs, in addition, which will see that our medical care for the aged are - is - are much - is much better handled than it is at the present time.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Here again, may I indicate that Senator Kennedy and I are not in disagreement as to the aims.
Speech: Here again, may I indicate that Senator Kennedy and I are not in disagreement as to the aims.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We both want to help the old people.
Speech: We both want to help the old people.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We want to see that they do have adequate medical care.
Speech: We want to see that they do have adequate medical care.
Speaker: NIXON
Name: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The question is the means.
Speech: The question is the means.
